page.text: Daniel D. Lee – Vice Chair – District 4
Tammie Collins – Division Chief of Planning & Community Development
Gene Jones – Director of County Building & Grounds Maintenance
VI. Environmental Studies – see Appendix A
The goal of this Master Plan assignment is to explore, outline and formalize a
long-range strategy for the comprehensive development of the Government
Center Campus of Dinwiddie County. The work is to examine the site for
existing, proposed and future capacity, building arrangement, vehicular
circulation and parking. Also, it is to evaluate the best design approach for
utilities including water, sanitary sewer, electric, and data & communications
services. Further, the plan will address environmental issues, site grading, site
and storm water drainage, and future landscaping. The work will also layout
preliminary schedules for implementing the proposed projects.
All in all, the Master Plan should be an instructive document that sets out a long
term guide for the phased and orderly development of the Government Center,
so as to best meet the needs of the citizens of Dinwiddie for years to come.
This Master Plan documentation is a descendant of information gained during
the Dinwiddie County Government Center Study/ 2012, in which our team
completed a 1-Facilities Survey and Evaluation, conducted a 2-Space Needs
Assessment and prepared a series of 3- Master Plan Studies & Budget options
Comprised of some six individual Site Plan drawings, the Master Plan describes
the expansion of the current Dinwiddie County Government Center Campus to
allow for three new buildings while certain current buildings are reassigned. In
addition to the proposed expansion, the Master Plan also documents the
potential for future expansion in the years ahead.
Site 1 is property currently owned by the County, located to the southwest of the Dinwiddie Courthouse and
beyond the retention basin north of the Pamplin Building. This site is heavily wooded with a natural drainage
swail crossing the site, parallel to the inner boundary. The existing contours are somewhat severe, fluctuating
from 229 to 271, with a mean average of 255-260, at the probable building pad. The approach to this parcel
would be a newly constructed roadway passing either through the existing storm retention basin, or through an
existing easement. The new road would activate a 50 foot easement that follows the joint property lines in the
rear of the Courthouse proper, traversing a distance of some 975' +/- from Courthouse Road.
Development of this parcel is eventually possible, but various existing constraints lower its ranking to last of the
All new utilities would need to be extended from the existing water, sewer, storm drainage, electrical
power, communications, and information technology systems. The capacities of these systems are
not known at this time, and must be verified before extension.
The parcel is located away from the main campus. Any new structure placed there, without the
accompaniment of other structures, would be situated in a somewhat remote location.
In critiquing this parcel, we do not want to downplay its long term value to the County. Sometime in the future, it
could be extended and coupled with the timely acquisitions of the several other residential parcels directly
behind the Courthouse. It is important to note that any acquisition of the residential parcels once combined with
the main campus would create long term expansion possibilities not now present; and heighten security for the
If and when any of these three residential parcels to the west, should become available, in a fair market
environment, it is suggested that the County consider purchase as a strategic option.
Provides a single-story footprint of 24,000 s.f. based on a
There is no current pressing need for the development of
Site 1, in that current projected space needs can be met
at Site 2 and Site 3, on a more efficient and economical
Site 1 should be reserved for future growth/expansion
once the infrastructure and buildable areas of Site 2 and
Site 2 is wooded property, currently owned by the County and is well situated adjoining the Courthouse to the
North. Also, it has direct access to Courthouse Road, and a fifty foot (50') wide jointly held roadway easement
that follows along the North boundary.
Access to this particular site can be by way of the Courthouse parking lot, or from Courthouse Road proper. It
can also be accessed from a section of the proposed new roadway / easement, noted above.
This feature of being more accessible, and having direct highway access, is a bonus that Site 1 does not have.
The advantage of location near the Courthouse, and easy accessibility to other facilities would prove to be a
significant aid to the overall campus security program.
Topographically Site 2 has much gentler and workable terrain than Site 1, and appears to contain no significant
storm drainage issues. Also, the extension of infrastructure such as water, sewer, electric power, telephone, IT,
and storm drainage, would require a shorter route than Site 1. This alone will lower overall development costs
This parcel, being in good proximity to the Courthouse is particularly well suited as the location for a proposed
new Public Safety Building. Said structure would then combine the Sheriff's Office, Fire & EMS offices, as well
as the E.O.C. Suite. The parcel is on high ground and provides good visibility not only of the Courthouse
Grounds, but also the balance of the Campus, including the positive effects of a “security triangulation”, offered
Provides a single-story footprint of 22,000 s.f. and a parking
capacity of 74 vehicles. Proximity to the Courthouse and
Highway gives this site optimal ranking for near-term.
There is current need for a new Public Safety Building of
15,400 s.f. +/- and 51 parking spaces, all of which can be
met at this site. The site is ideally suited for such use, in
that the Sheriff's Office can be placed adjacent to the
Courthouse, and, in a strategic oversight view of the
Site 2 should be reserved for the near-term development
for a new Public Safety facility that will house the Sheriff's
Office and the Fire/ EMS department; each
Generally, Site 3 is that specific parcel of County owned property at the front section of the Government Center
Campus, fronting along Boydton Plank Road. It is presently occupied by the old Social Services Building and
the Health Department Building, and other incidental infrastructure.
Currently, it is bisected by a central Roadway that takes traffic directly into the Courthouse, and has been
identified as a vulnerable security risk by both this office, and the security consultant for the County.
The site is fairly level along the higher mid-section, falling off some 10' to 12' towards the Courthouse parking
lot to the west. Properly addressed, this natural grade condition, could allow for an exposed lower level (English
Basement) along the western elevation of any new structure designed for this site.
Site 3 is highly desirable from the vantage points of public access, and civic presence; and because of its size
and location it could be successfully redeveloped as a “flagship” location for primary County Administration
This parcel is not without constraints; none however that cannot be resolved with careful planning. First, the
decommissioning of the old Social Services Building and the Health Department would need to take place.
Following that, critical infrastructure now serving those buildings would need to be cut, capped, and generally
reworked so as to allow for future construction. Additionally, areas of the existing roadway and parking would
need to be reworked / rearranged / expanded to accommodate any new development.
All in all this is an optimal site, The boundary along the street is graced with many mature trees, and its visibility
Provides a single-story footprint of 39,200 s.f. +/- and with
parking capacity of 180 vehicles; can ultimately provide a
multi-story capacity of 54,000 s.f. which can be met in
variable building configurations and level arrangements.
This is a highly visible site at the front of the campus with
There is current need for both a new Human Services
Facility of some 19,100 s.f. and 64 parking spaces; as well
as a new Administration Facility of some 25,400 s.f. and
Site 3 should be reserved for the near-term development
of both a Human Services Facility of 19,100 s.f. and 64
parking spaces, as well as an Administration Facility of
25,400 s.f. and 85 parking spaces. Since it has a prominent
location, this site would provide the best location for both of
these frequently visited facilities, access to Boydton Plank
In that there is limited space available for building expansion on either side and rear of the present Courthouse;
and limited space available for a modest addition to the west of the Pamplin Building; we turn to the three
primary “new building” sites available, within the present campus.
The possibility for additional building sites beyond the three noted, would lie in the acquisition of several
residential parcels to the west beyond the Courthouse, and the service station lot at the North East corner. Both
of these options are not feasible at this time.
Should the service station parcel ever become available a relocation and realignment of Courthouse Road, as it
intersects with Boydton Plank Road, would allow the Main Campus to be expanded effectively and bring to it
added beauty, security, and spatial continuity.
Overall, Site 1 should be reserved for future growth/ expansion once the infrastructure
and buildable areas of Site 2 and Site 3 are completed. Site #2 should be reserved for
the near term development of a new Public Safety Building that will house the Sheriff's
Department and the Fire/ EMS Department. Site 3 – Central Campus, should be
reserved for the near term development of both a Human Services Facility as well as
taken in large part from the

School Board at a later date, with minimum disruption to the

Additionally, the vehicular traffic, street access, and parking

Government Center Campus does have one unoccupied
site that meets the requirements of being on the highway and
being adjacent to the Courthouse. This is Site 2
Provide a new or existing / renovated facility to house various
departments of the County and Administration in updated /
enlarged / enhanced office space to include, but not be limited
I.T. (Information Technology) may be removed from this priority
should the decision be made to retain them in the Pamplin
Building or relocate them to the Fire/ EMS Building
Fire/ EMS Building at a later
date. Their Space Needs remain, as shown here.
This option evaluates an all new Administrative Facility at the
Government Center on a site to be selected / developed with
good visibility, good highway access and well planned and
adequate parking. This would be a stand alone building that is
sited / constructed such that future expansion is easily
achieved. The design of such a facility should plan for both
The new construction approach would provide advantages that
include only one move for Administration, but also place them
in all new offices that can better address the present space
needs, and those of the future. Placing the Administration
offices in a new facility sited at a central and key location, will
serve the public well. It would also help to optimize the
Masterplan concept now being considered in this study.
We find Site 3 to be the highly preferred location. The need to
decommission the existing Social Services and Health
Department buildings will come into play, as this site is
details as to how this project fits in the Masterplan
Evaluate providing a new or existing renovated facility to house
the collective administrative offices of the Dinwiddie County
School Board. At this time the School Board
bifurcated with major offices at the Pamplin Building, and other
support offices off-site. This is not a desirable situation from an
Develop a re-assignment of the first floor of the Pamplin
Building, subject to the re-location of the Administration Suite
School Board Offices in the Lower Level are too
small and there is no expansion room. Presently, the School
Board uses approximately 4,800 sf +/- of the Lower Level. Their
space needs are set at 10,520 sf +/-, which can be satisfied on
the first floor of the Pamplin Building
others would be available on the Lower Level. All budget
New Construction is not considered in this priority in that
adequate space in existing buildings can be made available.
The two sites considered are the Pamplin Building
Annex Buildings A & B at the Middle School Complex.
School Board is located in the Pamplin Building
and has been for some time past. Of the two renovation sites
considered, the Pamplin Building is the better suited and as
such, proves to be the most cost effective option.
The annex site has the disadvantage of being an older
classroom building that will be more difficult to retro-fit. Also,
Annex Buildings are more remote to the public, and
situated to the rear of the site, bringing into question, security
as to how this project fits into the overall Masterplan
Provide a renovated facility to house the Virginia Tech Extension
Services, now in leased space off-site near the Government
Extension Services is satisfied generally with the
present location, however some enhancements / expansion of
Evaluate the viability of providing renovated / enhanced space
somewhere within a County owned facility.
The overall need of the Extension Services
Extension Services are fairly limited in
scope as compared to those of others. Specifically, their need
for an enlarged meeting room suited to education and special
activities is most important, but not critical time-wise.
In that the proposed demolition of the Old Jail can take place
near term, and a modest renovation of the existing Sheriff's
Office, could provide a suitable home for Extension Services; it
is suggested that their re-location and enhancements wait until
the Public Safety facility is completed, and the existing Sheriff's
A new construction option was not considered for Extension
Services. The renovation budget shown can be applied to an
alternate location, should one other than this site be selected
taken in large part from the
The County can/ will address the needs for a Human Services Facility first, by
building an all new combined structure at Site 3 to sufficiently accommodate
Social Services, Health Department and Comprehensive Services. This facility
would accent individual suite identities; all with preferred adjacencies, and at the
same time provide good public access and parking.
This new facility could be either a stand alone structure near the proposed
Administration Building, or it could be connected as a wing of that (anticipated)
larger Administration structure. In either case it is suggested that it's placement
be in concert with the master planning, and building design guidelines
envisioned for the overall campus and provided herein.
By taking Human Services first, the County can limit the time at the current “off-
site” temporary location of Health and Social Services at the Middle School.
Their near term relocation will free the Middle School site for reassignment to its
The County can/ will address the needs for public safety, with an all new
combined facility at Site 2 to house Sheriff, Fire & Emergency Medcial Services
(EMS) in a single state-of-the-arts structure that will also house an updated
Emergency Operations Center (EOC) to be used by both, and the County staff
The first choice of location for the facility is Site 2, the benefits of which have
been outlined elsewhere in this report. The second choice of location would be
for the Public Safety facility to be built at Site 3, possibly as an adjacent
structure, or as a compatible wing of the (anticipated) new Administration
The need of overall campus security and accessibility, places Site 2 as the
preferred location for a new Public Safety Facility. The capacity of Site 2 fits
nicely with the needs of the proposed Public Safety Facility.
The County can/ will address the needs of County Administration by providing
an all new facility to house the ten (10) selected departments as the center
piece for Site 3, thus becoming the “flagship” building of the County.
Possibly, this facility's construction will become a second step of a two-step
effort wherein the Human Services Facility is brought online first, and the
Administrative offices are then followed as funding permits.
If it should be determined by the leadership to bring Public Safety to Site 3,
rather than Site 1, this would alter the sequence by becoming the second step;
thus pushing Administration offices to the third and final Step,
While this facility may well come to be the second or third phase in the overall
building exercise at Site 3; ultimately the three phases should combine into a
complete and unified design as a single complex.
The County may address the needs of Dinwiddie School Board Offices with a
relocation / reassignment of their “combined offices” into the first floor of the
Pamplin Building, once it has been vacated by the Administration and modestly
refurbished to meet their needs. Also, a portion of the Lower Level (Old School
Board Offices) would be refurbished for the Department of Information
Technology (I.T.), thereby releasing the existing trailers and eliminating all “rent”
In parallel with Step 4, address the needs of the Extension Services by
relocating them to the Old Sheriff's Offices behind the Historic Courthouse once
the Old Jail has been removed, the Sheriff's Offices relocated, and moderate
This site will afford the Extension Services a place of relative autonomy and a
zone of adaptable and usable outdoor space, all to better serve their special
Step 1 Administration / Human Services / Public Safety
The County can/ will address the needs of Human Services, Public Safety and
Administration in an all new County Facility at Site 3, as opposed to the first
three steps shown in Solution A. As envisioned, this facility would provide
collectively for the space and growth requirements of these three groupings, all
Conceptually, a facility of this nature is envisioned as having a strong central
element housing the 10 core Administrative Offices of some 25,200 sf; and
accompanied by two major flanking wings, one to house Human Services at
approximately 19,100 sf, and another to house Public Safety at approximately
15,100 sf, for a total of 59,400 sf overall.
While this would be a more aggressive approach than the sequenced steps
outlined in Solution A, it would, in one comprehensive step, resolve all of the
various space deficiencies and growth requirements for the greater majority of
departments. School Board, IT and Extensions Services would not be part of
this, and are addressed next in Step 2.
The County can/ will address the needs of the combined administrative offices
of the School Board by relocating / expanding within the existing Pamplin
Building, once the Administration offices are relocated.
Also, address the needs the needs of IT in parallel and following the School
Board relocation by refurbishing a section of the lower level of the Pamplin
In parallel with Step 2, address the needs of the Extension Services by
relocating them to the Old Sheriff's Offices behind the Historic Courthouse –
once the Old Jail has been removed, Sheriff's Offices relocated, and moderate
This site will afford the Extension Services a place of relative autonomy and a
zone of adaptable and usable outdoor space, all to better serve their special
As presently prepared for Master Plan/ 2014, budget figures summarized
here are shown as Pre-Design figures associated with standard new
construction or renovation projects. The project model assumes a
Design/ Bid/ Build approach in an open market environment.
These figures generally include: a.) Sitework – to include grading, paving,
curbs & gutters, etc. associated directly with the project; b.) Building-
Construction – to include general building costs associated with the
Contract for Construction along with finishes, flooring and casework; and
related c.) Other Costs – to include architectural/ engineering design, legal
work, survey, testing, printing and other miscellaneous costs.
Figures are drawn/ compiled from a history of other similar projects
within the region. Figures are subject to variation and development of the
Figures do not include Owner provided features such as furnishings and
equipment, communication systems, information technology, security, or
In summary, the figures shown are limited to those generally associated
with building costs of any given project, and are calculated in current
dollars. An estimated inflation factor of 2% to 3% per year is to be
anticipated for each year out that the project is extended.
a 5 step plan of development spanning 5 to 6 years
a 3 step plan of development spanning 4 to 5 years
The budget numbers shown herein are for utility infrastructure
improvements that are not typically associated with an individual
Budget numbers are included for a new private well and associated
tanks and pumps to provide domestic service and fire service to the
entire complex. New water main lines and fire hydrants are also
included. Costs for individual domestic service and fire service lines,
connections and meters are not included. Same shall be included in the
Likewise, budget numbers are included for new sanitary sewer main
lines to serve the entire campus. Budget numbers are also included to
upgrade the existing sewer pump station to accommodate all proposed
development as shown on the master plan. However, costs for
individual building sewer service lines and connections are not
Budget numbers are included for BMP’s and new storm sewer
structures and piping to serve the entire campus. The subject storm
sewer infrastructure shall capture runoff from the individual building
sites and route same to central BMP facilities and down-gradient
receiving channels. The costs for miscellaneous catch basins and
piping around the building footprints are not included. Same shall be
included in the individual building construction budgets.
Last, budget numbers are included to provide a new fiber optic
communication loop, with hand-holes, around the entire campus. The
costs to make individual building connections are not included. Same
shall be included in the individual building construction budgets.
